Class List

java.lang.Object
  project3.three.Node
      project3.three.List
Direct Known Subclasses:
DatalogSegment, NamedList, PredicateList
public abstract class List
extends Node

The generalized List class. 

 Domain Definition:
     nodes : SequenceOf<Node>

 Instance Invariant:
     nodes ≠ null -- though it may be empty

Source Code
Method Detail

createList

public void createList(Lex lex)
                throws ParserException
CreateList is a general list constructor. It is customized in a subclass by possibly overridding the methods:
  • createNode(Lex) -- Should be overridden in every specialization. By defining it to create only instances of X (X must be a specialization of Node), then we can restrict the specialization of List to be a list of X.
  • getSeparator(Lex) -- When parsing a list, some lists are separated by commas and some are not. This method defines whether it is comma separated or not.
  • isInFirstOfListElement(Lex) -- Different lists must start with different kinds of tokens (e.g. some must start with an Identifier and others may start with Constants). This method defines what kind of Token a list must start with.
  • getLengthConstraint(Lex) -- Some lists are lists are lists of 0 or more elements. Other lists are lists of 1 or more elements. This is overridden to define which type of list we are woking with.

See their descriptions below.

Normally, this code would go in the List(Lex) constructor, but, in the subclasses this code needs to be executed after doing some processing. In a method we can do some processing and then call the same method in the superclass. But, with a constructor we must call the constructor in the superclass first. We are unable do any processing or checking first. So, we have the constructor call a method method that does some processing and then calls createList(Lex) method. In some sense, createList(Lex) is the constructor, for the class List.

Precondition: lex ≠ null
Postcondition: a list of Nodes is created according to the 4 methods identified.

Parameters:
lex - the lexical analyzer we will create the List from.j
Throws:
ParserException
See Also:
Source Code

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Converts the list to a string. The method getSeparator() defines the separator used in this list. It returns null if there is no separator. It is overridden in a subclass if the subclass has a separator, normally the comma.

Precondition: none
Postcondition: return a string representation of this list.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
the string representation of a List.

checkForFirstMemberOfTheList

protected boolean checkForFirstMemberOfTheList(Lex lex)
                                        throws ParserException
Checks to see if there is a first member of the list. Lists come in two forms: list of length 1 or more and lists of length 0 or more. The most common is a list of 1 or more members. If a list has 1 or more members, then this method should be a method that is constant and always returns true. This is the default implementation of this method.

Precondition: lex ≠ null
Postcondition: getListConstraint = ONE_OR_MORE ⇒ result = true AND
  getListConstraint = ZERO_OR_MORE ⇒ result = checkForAnotherMemberOfTheList(lex)

Parameters:
lex - the lexical analyzer we will check to for a first member of the List
Returns:
whether there must be a first member of the list.
Throws:
ParserException
See Also:
Source Code

checkForAnotherMemberOfTheList

protected boolean checkForAnotherMemberOfTheList(Lex lex)
                                          throws ParserException
Determines whether the next token is of the proper Type. We typically use this method to determine whether we are to continue parsing the elements of a list. In most cases, we check to see if the next token is an Identifier. Thus, this is the default behavior. In another case we check to see if the token is an Argument. In lists where there is a separator, we check for the separator, and, if it exists, consume it.

Precondition: none
Postcondition: getSeparator() == null ⇒ result = isInFirstOfListElement(lex) AND
  getSeparator() ≠ null ⇒ (lex.front().getTokenType() == getSeparator().getTokenType() AND lex = lex'.popFront())

Parameters:
lex - the lexical analyzer we will check to see if there is another member of the List
Returns:
whether there is a nother member of the list.
Throws:
ParserException
See Also:
Source Code

createNode

protected abstract Node createNode(Lex lex)
                            throws ParserException
This actually creates the node of the proper type. Almost every specialization of this list creates a member of a different type, T. But, T must be a subclass of Node. This method is overridden to create a node of a the proper type. Usually it looks like this:

   return new T(lex);

Precondition: the front part of the input file is a syntatically correct representation of an instance of T.
Postcondition: result = the new instance of T, and Lex have been updated appropriately.

Throws:
ParserException
See Also:
Source Code

getSeparator

protected Token getSeparator()
If there is a separator, it returns a token representing the separator, otherwise it returns null. By default it returns null. It needs to be overridden for FactList, RuleList, and QueryList.

Precondition: none
Postcondition: hasSeparator ⇒ result = appropriate separator AND
  ¬ has Separator ⇒ result = null

Returns:
The separator between elements of the list. null means there is no separator.
See Also:
Source Code

isInFirstOfListElement

protected boolean isInFirstOfListElement(Lex lex)
If we have a list of elements of type T, this determines if lex.front() is in the first of T. Normally there is a set of token types associated with a the first of of type T, but, in this grammar the set only has a single type, usually, Identifier. Thus, the default check is to check for an Identifer. In Predicates we override this method and check for Arguments.

Precondition: none
Postcondition: result = lex.front() instanceof Identifier

Parameters:
lex - we check lex[0] to see if it is of the appropriate type.
Returns:
wheter lex[0] is in the first of T for this List.
See Also:
Source Code

getLengthConstraint

protected List.LengthConstraint getLengthConstraint()
If the list must have one or more members, then return ONE_OR_MORE, else return ZERO_OR_MORE. By default we assume that a list must have one or more elements. It is possible to have lists with other contraints on their lengths (e.g. 2 or more). We have designed this so we can change the enumerated type and change this method to accomodate other contraints. However, for this project, as it stands, we need only return ONE_OR_MORE or ZERO_OR_MORE.

Precondition: none
Postcondition: the list must have one or more elements ⇒ result = LengthConstraint.ONE_OR_MORE AND
  the list need not have one or more elements ⇒ result = LengthConstraint.ZERO_OR_MORE

Returns:
a LengthConstraint indicating wheter this List has one or more members or zero or more members.
See Also:
